learning_outcomes.description: Related to spatial/cognitive skills - demonstrate a critical understanding of existing and emerging urban design theory, practice and policy making in Australia and internationally
Related to spatial/cognitive skills - analyse the built urban environment in a way that is cognizant of the social, environmental and cultural implications of urban form and pattern
Related to spatial/cognitive skills - develop an understanding of the urban design process
Related to design/practical skills/communication - review, compile and summarise salient concepts from relevant literature and other sources

Related to design/practical skills/communication - demonstrate the use, both individually and in groups, of urban design skills, including "Place-making" and graphic language, to communicate urban design concepts, logic, and strategy in a professional manner

assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Practical/ Demonstration, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale:

This assessment will be made of 4 assignments worth 5% each for a total of 20%. The assignments are to be submitted via Blackboard Ultra: Weeks 4, 6, 8, 10

Assignment 1: Site Mapping

Task: Using base maps and aerial imagery, students will produce a detailed tracing of the study area on Sketchup, identifying key elements of street hierarchy, open space structure, building footprints.

Submission format: One A3 analytical map + brief annotation (max 200 words)

Assignment 2: Lynch Diagramming

Task: Students will conduct a Kevin Lynch-inspired urban analysis, identifying elements such as nodes, edges, paths, districts, and landmarks in the project area. This will be accompanied by a conceptual urban structure diagram that captures spatial relationships and user experience.

Submission format: One A3 Lynch map + conceptual diagram

Assignment 3: Street Section Study – Existing and Proposed 

Task: Produce two street sections for the selected street:

• One showing the existing condition, including buildings, streetscape elements, setbacks, and movement types.

• One showing a proposed design intervention that enhances walkability, sustainability, and urban amenity.

Submission format: Two street sections (A3 horizontal format)

Assignment 4: Placemaking Intervention Concept

Task: Develop a placemaking concept plan for a targeted site. Students will identify a small-scale intervention (for example, sponge park, active frontage upgrade, street activation) and prepare a plan or axonometric view supported by a short narrative.

Submission format: One A3 concept board + 150-words design rationale

Assessment Criteria:

• Response to site context and community use

• Quality of spatial thinking

• Design communication and layout

Assessment task to be completed without use of AI or MT: This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The School of Architecture, Design and Planning uses Blackboard and Turnitin for assessment submission. Turnitin is accessed through the course Blackboard site. Turnitin also checks for plagiarism or instances where the original work of others is not appropriately acknowledged.  Students are advised to commence assignment uploads with sufficient amount of time (consider possible technical problems with computers, internet speed, etc). After successfully submitting an assignment through Turnitin, a ‘Submission Complete!’ screen will be displayed. It is the student’s responsibility to check assignment preview and confirm successful submission. If the ‘Submission Complete!’ screen isn’t displayed, the student should regard the submission as unsuccessful. Students should download a copy of the digital receipt as proof they have submitted the assignment. Students who are experiencing upload issues must advise the Course Coordinator immediately by email and should include screenshots and a copy of the assessment for submission. To meet professional accreditation, public engagement and quality assurance obligations, digital copies of all course assessment items must be submitted in addition to any hard copy submission requirements specified in individual Course / Studio Outlines. Any physical models should be photographed and a minimum of two photographs describing the complete and full model must be included in the digital submission.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale: 

The overall aim of this assignment is to engage students in representing key elements from the built environment (a site, a street, a building) from a designated urban area in West End. Students will use relevant software and incorporate an evaluation of performance when representing those items and will engage in 'Place-making' when proposing the improvement of a given street in the area. This assessment will be done in a team of 4 students maximum.

The outline of the portfolio is a follow (a template is available on Blackboard Ultra).

Format: A3, 30 pages maximum including references.

01 Context Analysis  

1.1 Introduction: West End and the City

1.2 Context Analysis: West End Neighbourhood

1.3 Space syntax analysis

1.4 Districts, Paths, Edges, Nodes, and Landmarks

1.5 Placemaking Analysis: Vitality, Fit, Access, Control, Sense

1.6 Street Section Current

1.7 Summary + Recommendations

02 Vision

03 Placemaking Proposed

3.1 Key Strategies

3.2 Street Section Proposed

04 Building Performance

05 References 

5.1 Appendix  

If, for whatever reason, you find that your group is not functioning effectively, please contact your Course Coordinator for support.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale: 

The final examination is about the Lecture content (concepts explained in the lecture slides) and the readings assigned every week (and available on Blackboard). A one-hour preparation for the final exam will be done on Week 13. The exam will include multiple choice questions and short answer question.

The break-up and weighting of questions will be as follows: 5 short answers * 8 points + 5 essay questions*12 points = 100 points.

Assessment task to be completed without use of AI or MT: This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Have your UQ student ID card available for all of your exams. Students enrolled in External delivery must attend the exam in-person at an approved off-campus venue.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture

Week 1 - Course Introduction (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 2 - Context Analysis in Urban Design (Dr. Ksenia Nikolaeva)

Week 3 - Site visit in West End (Dr. Sebastien Darchen/Dr. Ksenia Nikolaeva)

Week 4 - Stakeholders in urban design (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 5 - City Streets (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 6 - Place-making (Dr. Mubeen Ahmad)

Week 7 - Building performance (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 8 - Design and nightlife economy (Fortitude Valley Precinct) (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 9 - Postmodern Urbanism (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 10 - Urban regeneration through adaptive re-use (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 11 - Urban Design and AI (Dr. Ksenia Nikolaeva)

Week 12 - Preparation for the exam (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 13 - No lecture
